title: The Great American Coffee Taste Test Analysis
text: analyze data create visualizations, ’ll need following libraries: filtered dataset focus 6 key variables analysis. interested exploring full dataset 57 variables, can download directly TidyTuesday GitHub repository . data can accessed loading “coffee_survey” alternatively using code “CoffeeSurvey::coffee_survey”. can use following code look dataset.
code: # Install the necessary packages if not already installed install.packages(c("dplyr", "ggplot2", "plotly", "DT")) # Load the libraries library(CoffeeSurvey) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(plotly) library(DT) data("coffee_survey") head(coffee_survey) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   prefer_overall gender age             where_drink brew               most_paid #>   <chr>          <chr>  <chr>           <chr>       <chr>              <chr>     #> 1 NA             NA     18-24 years old NA          NA                 NA        #> 2 NA             NA     25-34 years old NA          Pod/capsule machi… NA        #> 3 NA             NA     25-34 years old NA          Bean-to-cup machi… NA        #> 4 NA             NA     35-44 years old NA          Coffee brewing ma… NA        #> 5 NA             NA     25-34 years old NA          Pour over          NA        #> 6 NA             NA     55-64 years old NA          Pod/capsule machi… NA

title: The Great American Coffee Taste Test Analysis
text: two simple examples showing explore data table plot. Feel free explore using similar methods.

title: The Great American Coffee Taste Test Analysis
text: first example shows respondents typically drink coffee (home, office, cafe, etc.). majority respondents (86.9%) reported consuming coffee home, followed 7.5% office, 3.8% cafe, 1.7% go, highlighting strong preference home-based coffee consumption.
code: # Filter and calculate percentages for coffee consumption locations where_drink_distribution <- coffee_survey |>   filter(!is.na(where_drink)) |>   filter(where_drink %in% c("At home", "At the office", "At a cafe", "On the go")) |>   count(where_drink) |>   mutate(percentage = n / sum(n) * 100) |>   arrange(desc(percentage)) summary_table <- where_drink_distribution |>   select(     Location = where_drink,                       `Percentage Responded` = percentage           ) |>   mutate(`Percentage Responded` = round(`Percentage Responded`, 1)) |>     arrange(desc(`Percentage Responded`))  datatable(summary_table)

title: The Great American Coffee Taste Test Analysis
text: second example visualizes overall preferences different coffee types. Overall Perferences Coffee D (experimental Colombian coffee) popular choice, 36.7% votes. suggests consumers open trying unusual, fermented flavor profiles. Coffee (light-roast Kenyan) followed closely behind 21.7% votes, indicating strong market lighter, fruitier coffee options.
code: # Define colors for coffees coffee_colors <- c(   "Coffee A" = "#8B4513",   "Coffee B" = "#D2B48C",   "Coffee C" = "#C19A6B",   "Coffee D" = "#4B3832")  popularity <- coffee_survey |>   filter(!is.na(prefer_overall)) |>   count(prefer_overall) |>   mutate(percentage = n / sum(n) * 100) |>   arrange(desc(n)) gg1 <- ggplot(popularity, aes(x = prefer_overall, y = percentage, fill = prefer_overall)) +       geom_bar(stat = "identity") +       labs(title = "Popularity of Coffee Types",            x = "Coffee Type",            y = "Percentage of Votes") +       scale_fill_manual(values = coffee_colors) +       theme_minimal() +       theme(         plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),         axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),         axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12)       )  ggplotly(gg1)
